HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 12, 1926.

HULLABALOO VOTING
THROWN OPEN AGAIN
According to an announcement made by President Lord
of the Junior class, the voting for Editor-in-Chief and
Business Manager of the Hullabaloo was so thin that none
of the candidates was elected.
Under the new class constitution a majority vote of the
class is necessary to elect a
man to office. The candidates
are Charles Reese for Editorin-Chief and O'Dunne, Abrahams and Bortner for Business Manager.
The polls will be reopened
today from twelve thirty until one, under the supervision
of the Student Council. Only
those members of the class
who have not voted previously will be entitled to a vote.

Miss Kay Fields of the Maryland Institute was pronounced
winner of the Barnstormers Club
poster contest. The judgment was
made by Mr. and Mrs. Swindell
and members of the club at the
rehearsal last Saturday afternoon.
Miss Fields, who won from a field
of some twenty odd, will receive a
box at one of the performances
next month. No decision has been
reached in the program cover contest.
The rehearsal was the first one
held since Mr. Swindell's return
from Europe, and he was delighted
with the progress the club has
made on the production during'
his absence. Mr. Swindell returning on the Steamer Olympic, had
the misfortune of being on the
ship when it encountered the worst

.1. J. Scherr, the Blue Jay

its leader last winter has returned to this University for

his degree. The former leader
made his return debut at the
Tea Dance at Lehmann's Art
Centre last Saturday. He
will play with :the Twin Six
for the rest of the year.
If anything, Scherr's playing, seasoned by several
months with Paul Whiteman's Second Band in New
York, is superior to the high
calibre furnished last winter.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 12, 1926.

THE PUBLICITY BOARD
• After years of almost supine existence, the Publicity Board
is at last to be called upon to make a good defense of itself, or
be abolished by the Student Activities Council. The move is
praiseworthy. All useless organizations should be removed from
the Campus, and unless the Publicity Board can convince us
by strong arguments to the contrary, we must admit its uselessness, and advocate its consignment to the limbo.

MEN'S RIGHTS
"It is to laugh," said some, when they read of the recent
shaving episode at a western university. It seems that a
tolerant professor told the men that they had just as much right
to shave their ugly faces in the class-room as the women had
to powder their shiny noses. Taking the unwary "profs" at his
word, two students entered the clas sthe next day, equipped with
razors, soap, and towels, and proceeded to shave themselves
during the lecture, to the immense amusement and satisfaction
of the class. However, the professor proved to be a good sport,
and awarded the shavers A's for the semester, stating that he
admired the way in which they stood up for men's rights.
There is much meat in the incident. The long and constant
fight for "Women's Rights" has caused a corresponding depression in the rights of the so-called sterner sex. It is high
time for men to rally around the flag, to fight fOr their liberties.
Hopkins has seen something of the battle. By the wise and
forunate provision in the will of Johns Hopkins, (or was it incorporated in Dr. Gilman's plan?), the undergraduate school
is not co-educational. Nevertheless, woman has from time to
time crept into the sacred precincts of the male. Even now, in
one of our classes, we can swear that there are at least three of
the unfair sex, airing their deficient knowledge and pulling down
excellent grades. The professors are not immune to their wiles.
One brave instructor, though, actually had the temerity to ask
one of the dears a question. She has not appeared in the class
since.
While we are not women haters, and while we admit that
they are very very essential at the proper time and place, we
hope that the powers that be will keep them out of the undergraduate classes. They are only an unnecessary distraction to
the toiling student.

OH BARN! OUR BARN
To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Dear Sir:
Never, since Adatu was given the
Garden of Eden to dress and keep,
has a structure been so appropriately named as our own -Barn."
What pleasant associations attached to the immortal barn!
How many s of us can remember
the romps we had in the old hay
stack, and the time we unknowingly rolled into the wasp's nest?
The old barn, the dear old barn,
with its pungent 'odors, its great
oozy mires, its adjoining pig pen,
and its smoking ordures. The old
barn, sweet to the memory of the
boy who has been blessed with a
sojourn in the sticks. With all its
reek and filth and odor, we adore
it.

but there we must stop, because
it is apparent that the conversion
is only fiction. The old barn is

The question is sometimes asked:
Where do young men get when
they enter a large industrial organization? Have they opportunity to
exercise creative talents, or are they
forced into narrow grooves?

CC

This series of advertisements
throws light on these questions. Each
advertisement takes up the record of
a college man who came with the
Westinghouse Company after graduation and within the past ten years.

Engineer! .„

HE Sales Department was
talking in emphatic and easily
understood language. It was saying,"We want action."
At Westinghouse,action in many
cases is another word for research.
JOSEPH SLEPIAN And research works toward selected
goals. In this case the goal was for new apparatus
to make unchained lightning more respectful of
power plants, lines and equipment.
Today, as a consequence, the electrical industry
is the beneficiary of the "Autovalve Lightning
Arrester", perfected to a degree of efficiency, long
service and universal utility never dreamed of before. Behind that picture you find Joseph Slepian.
With two degrees from Harvard, he started
training in our East Pittsburgh Shops in 1916.
A year later he entered the Research Department.
This was the lightning arrester situation which
Slepian took into the research camp: There were
two different types of apparatus. One, called the
multi-gap, was used chiefly on poles of distribution circuits. When lightning struCk, it frequently

T

DRAPERIES

caused transformer troubles and damaged equipment. For high-voltage application there was
the cumbersome electrolytic arrester. Its performance was good enough. But it required constant attention; was costly of upkeep; and could
not be used on poles.
When Slepian perfected the Autovalve Arrester, the demand was so great that orders could not
be filled. It was entirely new. One type of apparatus solved the whole problem—no more
costly care. It stands up indefinitely, whether
used on poles or on the ground—sufficient
reasons for yearly sales exceeding 52,000,000.
Such results may depend as much on a phase of
an engineer's past training as on his immediate research. Take the radio horn which gives the natural
tone to Radiola sets. It was Slepian's mastery
of mathematics, in which he specialized at Harvard, which contributed toward that big advance
in the early days of loud-speaker popularity.
The man with "hidden reserves" is constantly
finding them called upon to "climb peaks and cross
mountains" in institutions like Westinghouse.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 12, 1926.

You

FELLOWS
Are "up Against

a Great
Responsibility".'

ITHIN a short time you will be called upon to make a great decision. That
decision is going to leave its impression on civilization for generations to come.
You can't approach such a responsibility hastily, carelessly or flippantly and
be true to your self.
You can't point 'thumbs down' and continue to walk on the same thought plane with
Gilman, Gildersleeve, Rowland, Rernsen and Brooks.
We have but one excuse for addressing Hopkins undergraduates and alumni upon this
vital Hopkins problem.
We at first approached this question with misgivings, doubts and minds circumscribed
by selfish prejudices—
We had but slight understanding of the fundamental rightness of the advocated plans
which have been conceived to enlighten and serve humanity—
But we made it our business to get the reaction of eminent
thinkers and the cold-blooded analytical opinions of the
country's outstanding promoters of World Progress.
We have seen the light and sincerely believe that we may
be helpful to you in getting down to the necessity of having
every Hopkins undergraduate and every Hopkins Alumnus
and every Hopkins friend behind our leaders,--backing
them to the limit in the epoch-making work of making
Johns Hopkins the best research school in the country.
Right off the bat let's agree that a great objective can
never be attained without sacrifices.
We believe that the men who are and have been intimately
identified with Hopkins undergraduate life—men to whom
Hopkins' college spirit has been an all powerful influence
will be called upon to bear their share of the sacrifices.
We well understand what it means to think of Hopkins
without a Freshman class—without a Sophomore class.
We know what it has meant during that first year to learn
how to be sweetly humble and during that second year to
teach humility to others.
We know the thrill that comes only in a "class rush"—in
a Freshman-Sophomore football game.
We know the joys of hazing and being hazed; of breaking
up a class banquet and the chagrin of having one broken up.
We know the taste of victory and the pangs of defeat in
competition with our rivals on the field.
Yes, we know because we have been part of it. We lived
it for two solid years before we realized that there was
real work to do and that we must be "up and doing."

But there is no such purpose in mind.
Men entering Hopkins will come with varied backgrounds,
presenting the best that each has to offer from which will
develop a more comprehensive, a more influential, a more
constructive University spirit and "Esprit de Corps"
than ever before.
This would not have been so in years gone by.
A student formerly went into research largely to fit himself
to teach others.
It was not unusual to find him the proverbial grind.
But not so today.
World activities and problems are calling for scholars—
men who know. But to know is not sufficient. One must
know and know how to discover and to apply their discoveries in solving the problems of a cold-blooded, practical "survival of the fittest World."
That's the type you are going to see at Hopkins in the new
era.
That's the type which will evolve a spirit at Hopkins destined to be the pattern for the University World.
You are face to face with your great responsibility
great opportunity.

your

Get on the band wagon and get on quick.
Don't stand on the side-lines.
Don't get run over.
Don't just hang on.
Get right up in the driver's seat—

If the Hopkins men of tomorrow were to be denied acquaintance with Freshman-Sophomore life, then in our opinions
these men would be handicapped in starting on their way
towards their bigger work.

Crack the whip and let the world know that you and your
side-kicks are out to clear the way for the great procession
that is to follow.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 12, 1926.

HULLABALOO VOTING
THROWN OPEN AGAIN
According to an announcement made by President Lord
of the Junior class, the voting for Editor-in-Chief and
Business Manager of the Hullabaloo was so thin that none
of the candidates was elected.
Under the new class constitution a majority vote of the
class is necessary to elect a
man to office. The candidates
are Charles Reese for Editorin-Chief and O'Dunne, Abrahams and Bortner for Business Manager.
The polls will be reopened
today from twelve thirty until one, under the supervision
of the Student Council. Only
those members of the class
who have not voted previously will be entitled to a vote.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 12, 1926.

THE PUBLICITY BOARD
• After years of almost supine existence, the Publicity Board
is at last to be called upon to make a good defense of itself, or
be abolished by the Student Activities Council. The move is
praiseworthy. All useless organizations should be removed from
the Campus, and unless the Publicity Board can convince us
by strong arguments to the contrary, we must admit its uselessness, and advocate its consignment to the limbo.

MEN'S RIGHTS
"It is to laugh," said some, when they read of the recent
shaving episode at a western university. It seems that a
tolerant professor told the men that they had just as much right
to shave their ugly faces in the class-room as the women had
to powder their shiny noses. Taking the unwary "profs" at his
word, two students entered the clas sthe next day, equipped with
razors, soap, and towels, and proceeded to shave themselves
during the lecture, to the immense amusement and satisfaction
of the class. However, the professor proved to be a good sport,
and awarded the shavers A's for the semester, stating that he
admired the way in which they stood up for men's rights.
There is much meat in the incident. The long and constant
fight for "Women's Rights" has caused a corresponding depression in the rights of the so-called sterner sex. It is high
time for men to rally around the flag, to fight fOr their liberties.
Hopkins has seen something of the battle. By the wise and
forunate provision in the will of Johns Hopkins, (or was it incorporated in Dr. Gilman's plan?), the undergraduate school
is not co-educational. Nevertheless, woman has from time to
time crept into the sacred precincts of the male. Even now, in
one of our classes, we can swear that there are at least three of
the unfair sex, airing their deficient knowledge and pulling down
excellent grades. The professors are not immune to their wiles.
One brave instructor, though, actually had the temerity to ask
one of the dears a question. She has not appeared in the class
since.
While we are not women haters, and while we admit that
they are very very essential at the proper time and place, we
hope that the powers that be will keep them out of the undergraduate classes. They are only an unnecessary distraction to
the toiling student.

To the Editor of the News-Letter.
Dear Sir:
I read with interest the newspaper accounts of non-athletic activities at several of our American institutions of higher education. In last night's edition of
one of our Baltimore papers I
read, "Sixteen Students on Probation for Kidnapping Episode."
"Pine," I say, wetting my lips in
anticipation, "oh, yes, a well
known college in Annapolis; oh,
Yes!" I turn a page. Screaming
headlines, "Junior's Back Broken
In Rum Revel! As a climax to an
orgy that started on New Year's
Eve and continued for two nights
and a day, * * * a junior * * * is
near death with a broken back."

oh, gentlemen, it is a sight to
make strong men break down and
weep like babes!
Think of our freshmen, of their
shattered illusions! Where, indeed, can they find true college
life; where can they see men in
high hats and pink combinations
holding up swaying lamp-posts;
where can they see raccoon coats
emerging from lowly gutters; oh,
where, forsooth, can they find collitch ? Don't you see how we are
cheating these innocent, trusting
boys? They had ideals, they had
faith in human nature, and then,
—they find this Kiwanian paradise, this haven for overworked
faith healers. No cocktail shakers in the memorial room, no kegs
in the Post Office,—oh, Shades of
Aristippus! Can nothing be done?
Won't you 'help me to restore
the glory of the "Elastic Age"?
The NEWS-LETTER'S suggestion to
the Blue Jay is a step in the right
direction. Come, join the crusade; help this bigger-better movement. Enlist the barn hounds
and the Tudor Stuart Club. Let
us stop hoodwinking the public
and our own fledglings. Let us,
indeed, have a college where men
are men. Let us out-Castor Castor. Will you do your bit?
If this is published, I will extoll the NEWS-LETTER till I'm
black in the face; I will arouse
The world with my praise of this
far-seeing, democratic, free-thinking paragon of journalism, while
if you don't I'll shout just as loudly that—that you're subsidized by
the Y. M. C. A.

The question is sometimes asked:
Where do young men get when
they enter a large industrial organization? Have they opportunity to
exercise creative talents, or are they
forced into narrow grooves?

CC

This series of advertisements
throws light on these questions. Each
advertisement takes up the record of
a college man who came with the
Westinghouse Company after graduation and within the past ten years.

Engineer! .„
Arrest that Bolt
HE Sales Department was
talking in emphatic and easily
understood language. It was saying,"We want action."
At Westinghouse,action in many
cases is another word for research.
JOSEPH SLEPIAN And research works toward selected
goals. In this case the goal was for new apparatus
to make unchained lightning more respectful of
power plants, lines and equipment.
Today, as a consequence, the electrical industry
is the beneficiary of the "Autovalve Lightning
Arrester", perfected to a degree of efficiency, long
service and universal utility never dreamed of before. Behind that picture you find Joseph Slepian.
With two degrees from Harvard, he started
training in our East Pittsburgh Shops in 1916.
A year later he entered the Research Department.
This was the lightning arrester situation which
Slepian took into the research camp: There were
two different types of apparatus. One, called the
multi-gap, was used chiefly on poles of distribution circuits. When lightning struCk, it frequently

T

DRAPERIES

caused transformer troubles and damaged equipment. For high-voltage application there was
the cumbersome electrolytic arrester. Its performance was good enough. But it required constant attention; was costly of upkeep; and could
not be used on poles.
When Slepian perfected the Autovalve Arrester, the demand was so great that orders could not
be filled. It was entirely new. One type of apparatus solved the whole problem—no more
costly care. It stands up indefinitely, whether
used on poles or on the ground—sufficient
reasons for yearly sales exceeding 52,000,000.
Such results may depend as much on a phase of
an engineer's past training as on his immediate research. Take the radio horn which gives the natural
tone to Radiola sets. It was Slepian's mastery
of mathematics, in which he specialized at Harvard, which contributed toward that big advance
in the early days of loud-speaker popularity.
The man with "hidden reserves" is constantly
finding them called upon to "climb peaks and cross
mountains" in institutions like Westinghouse.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 12, 1926.

You

FELLOWS
Are "up Against

a Great
Responsibility".'

ITHIN a short time you will be called upon to make a great decision. That
decision is going to leave its impression on civilization for generations to come.
You can't approach such a responsibility hastily, carelessly or flippantly and
be true to your self.
You can't point 'thumbs down' and continue to walk on the same thought plane with
Gilman, Gildersleeve, Rowland, Rernsen and Brooks.
We have but one excuse for addressing Hopkins undergraduates and alumni upon this
vital Hopkins problem.
We at first approached this question with misgivings, doubts and minds circumscribed
by selfish prejudices—
We had but slight understanding of the fundamental rightness of the advocated plans
which have been conceived to enlighten and serve humanity—
But we made it our business to get the reaction of eminent
thinkers and the cold-blooded analytical opinions of the
country's outstanding promoters of World Progress.
We have seen the light and sincerely believe that we may
be helpful to you in getting down to the necessity of having
every Hopkins undergraduate and every Hopkins Alumnus
and every Hopkins friend behind our leaders,--backing
them to the limit in the epoch-making work of making
Johns Hopkins the best research school in the country.
Right off the bat let's agree that a great objective can
never be attained without sacrifices.
We believe that the men who are and have been intimately
identified with Hopkins undergraduate life—men to whom
Hopkins' college spirit has been an all powerful influence
will be called upon to bear their share of the sacrifices.
We well understand what it means to think of Hopkins
without a Freshman class—without a Sophomore class.
We know what it has meant during that first year to learn
how to be sweetly humble and during that second year to
teach humility to others.
We know the thrill that comes only in a "class rush"—in
a Freshman-Sophomore football game.
We know the joys of hazing and being hazed; of breaking
up a class banquet and the chagrin of having one broken up.
We know the taste of victory and the pangs of defeat in
competition with our rivals on the field.
Yes, we know because we have been part of it. We lived
it for two solid years before we realized that there was
real work to do and that we must be "up and doing."

But there is no such purpose in mind.
Men entering Hopkins will come with varied backgrounds,
presenting the best that each has to offer from which will
develop a more comprehensive, a more influential, a more
constructive University spirit and "Esprit de Corps"
than ever before.
This would not have been so in years gone by.
A student formerly went into research largely to fit himself
to teach others.
It was not unusual to find him the proverbial grind.
But not so today.
World activities and problems are calling for scholars—
men who know. But to know is not sufficient. One must
know and know how to discover and to apply their discoveries in solving the problems of a cold-blooded, practical "survival of the fittest World."
That's the type you are going to see at Hopkins in the new
era.
That's the type which will evolve a spirit at Hopkins destined to be the pattern for the University World.
You are face to face with your great responsibility
great opportunity.

your

Get on the band wagon and get on quick.
Don't stand on the side-lines.
Don't get run over.
Don't just hang on.
Get right up in the driver's seat—

If the Hopkins men of tomorrow were to be denied acquaintance with Freshman-Sophomore life, then in our opinions
these men would be handicapped in starting on their way
towards their bigger work.

Crack the whip and let the world know that you and your
side-kicks are out to clear the way for the great procession
that is to follow.
